ext_description.p: A AlternatePartRelationship is a type of where the relating part represents the base part and the related part represents the alternate part.

It specifies that any version of the alternate part, may be used in place of any version of the base part, regardless of its usages and of its versions. The relationship established by the AlternatePartRelationship is not symmetric: if part B is an alternate part for part A, part A is not implied to be an alternate part for part B.
ext_description.note: If a part is an alternate for another part, it is understood that there is no interest in keeping track of which part, the base or any alternates specified, is used as a particular instance of the base part within a part structure

An organization may track design changes for a base part, and establish effectivity conditions for the use of that base part in various assemblies to be manufactured. The use of an alternate part implies that an organization does not specify any particular version of the alternate part nor establish effectivities relating to it
An AlternatePartRelationship may relate parts of any kind, provided both related objects identify parts of the same part category.
An AlternatePartRelationship for which the base part is an assembly involves that the entire part structure of the alternate part may be used in place of the base part and its part structure.

This concept usually refers to form, fit, function, and quality. Additional properties such as performance, noise, endurance, or reliability may also be considered as a prerequisite for the replacement
ext_description.example: Two bolts of the same size are parts. One bolt has a square head and the other has a hexagonal head. The two bolts are considered equivalent with respect to form, fit, and function: they both have sufficiently close physical shape, they take up the same space when used, and they both serve to fasten two things together. Thus, one of these two bolts could be considered to be an alternate part for the other bolt.

ext_description.p: the word or set of words describing the requirements that are covered by both the base part and the alternate part and therefore are the basis for the statement regarding the capability of replacing the base part by the alternate part.
ext_description.note: Additional properties such as performance, noise, endurance, or reliability may also be considered as a prerequisite for the replacement in addition to form, fit, function, and quality.
ext_description.p: The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the inherited attribute relationType. The value of relationType shall be 'alternate'.
The combination of the related part and the relating part shall be unique.

A Requirement is an essential characteristic, condition, or capability that shall be met or exceeded by a system or a component to satisfy a contract, standard, specification, or other formally imposed document. The term "requirement" is used here in the sense that term is used in systems engineering and similar industrial domains. There may be many versions of a Requirement through . There may also be more than one domain-specific view of a given (using the entity). The Requirement entity is simply a placeholder for holding a unique requirement. Most associations and properties could be defined at the Requirement, or level - that is in the context of a domain. A requirement may be identified as "NOx emissions requirement", and uniquely identified as "Req2". Systems engineering tools and organizations may use differing identification mechanisms. Multiple identifiers may be managed in Requirement using the id attribute.

ext_description.p: the identifier or set of identifiers for the Requirement. This attribute supports multi identification in different contexts as described in clause for fundamental concepts.
the words or set of words by which the Requirement is known. This attribute supports multiple names in different contexts as well as multi linguism.

ext_descriptions.ext_description: the text or the set of texts that provide further information about the Requirement. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the classifications of the Requirement. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the proxies of the Requirement. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the versions of the Requirement. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

A RequirementAssignment is used to relate a (via or ) to data types representing the items (specified in ) which are affected by the requirement. A requirement "the vehicle shall have a maximum power output of at least 150BHP" could be assigned to the data types which are used to represent the vehicle's engine.

ext_description.p: the identifier or set of identifiers for the RequirementAssignment. The value of this attribute need not be specified. This attribute supports multi identification in different contexts as described in clause for fundamental concepts.
the text or the set of texts that provide further information about the RequirementAssignment. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

ext_descriptions.ext_description: the classifications of the RequirementAssignment. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the or the which is assigned.
the item (specified in ) which has the requirement assigned to it.

A RequirementCollectionRelationship is a type of . It identifies a collection relationship that is used to relate a parent (collection) requirement to its member requirements. This provides a method for collecting together a set of requirements and treating them as a single requirement, whilst still being able to refer to individual requirements.

ext_description.p: the meaning of the relationship. Where applicable, the following class name shall be used:

ul.li: 'collection': the relationType specifies that the is a collection;

ext_descriptions.ext_description: A RequirementDecompositionRelationship is a type of . It identifies a decomposition relationship. This provides a method to represent a decomposition of requirements.

ext_description.p: the meaning of the relationship. Where applicable, the following class name shall be used:

ul.li: 'decomposition': the relationType specifies that the is a decomposition;

ext_descriptions.ext_description: A RequirementSatisfactionAssertion is a relationship between an item (specified in ) and a requirement (via or the ), asserting that the item satisfies the identified requirement. A data type used to represent a vehicle's engine with a power output of 160BHP could be asserted to satisfy a requirement "the vehicle shall have a maximum power output of at least 150BHP".

ext_description.p: the identifier or set of identifiers for the RequirementSatisfactionAssertion. The value of this attribute need not be specified. This attribute supports multi identification in different contexts as described in clause for fundamental concepts.

ext_descriptions.ext_description: the text or the set of texts that provide further information about the RequirementSatisfactionAssertion. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the classifications of the RequirementSatisfactionAssertion. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the date and the or the (via ) that has asserted the requirement satisfaction. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the that is satisfied by the RequirementSatisfactionAssertion. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the item (specified in ) that satisfies the requirement.
the requirement (via the or the ) that is satisfied.
A RequirementSequenceRelationship is a type of . It identifies a sequence relationship providing a method to link together , while introducing a particular order.

ext_description.p: the meaning of the relationship. Where applicable, the following class name shall be used:

ul.li: 'sequence': the relationType specifies that the is a sequence;

ext_descriptions.ext_description: A RequirementSourceAssociation is a relationship between a requirement (via the or the ) and the data types representing the source (specified in ) of the requirement. The source of the requirement "the vehicle shall have a maximum power output of at least 150BHP" could be a document representing the findings of a market survey of sports car buyers.

ext_description.p: the identifier or set of identifiers for the RequirementSourceAssociation. The value of this attribute need not be specified. This attribute supports multi identification in different contexts as described in clause for fundamental concepts.

ext_descriptions.ext_description: the text or the set of texts that provide further information about the RequirementSourceAssociation. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the classifications of the RequirementSourceAssociation. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the proxies of the RequirementSourceAssociation. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the item which is the source (specified in ) of the requirement.
the or the which is to be related to its source.

A RequirementTracingRelationship is a type of . It identifies a tracing relationship. A requirement on the performance of a catalytic converter in a car may be traced from a more general emissions requirement. A requirement may trace to many other requirements and vice versa - this is achieved by creating multiple instances of the tracing relationship entity.

ext_description.p: the meaning of the relationship. Where applicable, the following class name shall be used:

ul.li: 'tracing': the relationType specifies that the is a tracing relationship;

ext_descriptions.ext_description: A RequirementVersion identifies a particular version of a requirement. This entity is used to record different versions of a requirement. In this case, the word "version" implies "revision" - that is a particular release of a requirement. A given requirement might have versions 1.0, 1.1, 1.2 and 2.0.

ext_description.p: the identifier or set of identifiers for the RequirementVersion. This attribute supports multi identification in different contexts as described in clause for fundamental concepts.

the classifications of the RequirementVersion. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the proxies of the RequirementVersion. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the views of the RequirementVersion. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the that the RequirementVersion is a version of.
A RequirementVersionRelationship is a type of relationship that is used to relate previous version (related) of a requirement to the version that replaces it (relating).
the text or the set of texts that provide further information about the RequirementVersionRelationship. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the classifications of the RequirementVersionRelationship. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

ext_description.p: the meaning of the relationship. Where applicable, the following class name shall be used:

ul.li: 'sequence': the relationType specifies that the is a sequence;

ext_description.p: one object of that is part of the relationship. This object represent the new version of a requirement (via ) The semantics of this attribute are defined by the attribute relationType.
the other object of that is part of the relationship. This object represent the old version of a requirement (via ) The semantics of this attribute are defined by the attribute relationType.

ext_descriptions.ext_description: the related object and the relating object must not be the same .

A RequirementView provides a view of a requirement version relevant for one or more application domains. This view collects requirement data for specific engineering purposes. An engineer may have responsibility for collecting all requirements associated with the cooling of an engine - covering engine block, tubing, water pump, electric fan. Some requirements in a RequirementView might impact on different disciplines. Multiple RequirementView instances may be used to present different views of a given requirement for each discipline.
The definition of the requirement is represented by a set of definitional properties referenced from RequirementView.definitionalRepresentations. If more than one definitional property is provided each property shall be equivalent. Any other property that is associated with the RequirementView is assumed to be a non-defining property, such as an annotation etc. The requirement that the weight should be less than 4 Kgs can be represented by a string representation "weight must be 4Kg" and a numeric representation "4Kg" specified as a value with units.

ext_description.p: the identifier or set of identifiers for the RequirementView. The value of this attribute need not be specified. This attribute supports multi identification in different contexts as described in clause for fundamental concepts.

the proxies of the RequirementView. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
